content: other with each round until you have enough space for only one more decrease if you end up with just 1 stitch between each decrease you can do a decrease with all 3 remaining stitches once the circumference of the body of your sweater is set to however tight you want it around your stomach you will still need to add one decrease per row this is due to the additional stitch that you are adding in each ch1 space to keep the back section the same width throughout you will need to use alternating techniques for the decreases on each side for the first decrease of a round the stitch representing the decrease from the previous round should start your decrease so that you connect it to the stitch that starts your v on the second decrease of the round you will start your decrease with the stitch from the v and then connect it to the stitch representing the decrease from the previous round if you do not continue to add decreases on each side you will find that the front of your sweater is lengthening much faster than the back of your sweater if you want this to occur feel free to skip some or all of the decreases continue making rounds until the sweater has reached the length that you desire ending on a single_crochet round rather than sl to first stitch remove your hook after making your final single_crochet cut your yarn 6+ inches from the stitch and pull it through attach your yarn needle insert it into the stitch from your first single_crochet and then insert it into the stitch from your last single_crochet pulling tight tie off weave in the end step three make the sleeves repeat these steps for each side note if you are using a self-striping yarn like mandala you may need to cut your cake so that you are starting your yarn with the color that follows the one which ended your yoke start your yarn at the corner that will face the back the sleeves are made with rounds of double_crochet there are not any alternating row of single_crochet double_crochet in each stitch around the armhole make sure you count your stitches here this will help ensure that you have the same stitch count when you move to the other sleeve ch2 turn definitely try your sweater on at this point if the sleeve is too loose for the top of your arm decrease two times in each successive round moving the decreases closer together until there is room for just one more decrease if your upper arm gets larger after the shoulder add increases instead of decreases try it on again and make sure it is tight/loose enough i recommend placing your decreases/increases where the corners of the yoke had been this will hide the seam under your arm fiddle with the distance between the decreases/increases if the resulting circumference of the sleeve does not fit for
